awd_titl_txt: Workshop Proposal: Redefining the Future of Computer Architecture from First Principles
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern computer architecture is facing many new challenges introduced by emerging applications and technologies and experiencing unprecedented reformation in its foundational technologies across architecture, compiler, operating systems, software stack, and system integrations. The purpose of this project is to organize a National Science Foundation (NSF) sponsored online workshop named ``Redefining the Future of Computer Architecture from First Principles (Arch-1)". The workshop will be held at the end of March 2022. The participation in the workshop will be by invitation only, and the majority of the participants will be invited from academia, industry, government laboratories, and funding agencies by considering the representations of the expertise from all relevant research pillars. Underrepresented groups will be particularly encouraged to attend the workshop and receive priority in the considerations. This workshop will provide a forum for leading experts in the relevant research thrusts of computer architecture, specifically architecture, compiler, operating systems, software stack, system integration, and applications, to brainstorm the latest research progress and discuss their visions of redefining the future of computer architecture in the next 10-15 years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Present-day computer architecture designs face several severe challenges. On the one hand, insteadof running on homogeneous accelerators, executions of modern large-scale workloads ofteninvolve interactions between a number of heterogeneous devices across multiple layers of the developmentstack. The modifications in architectural design often have non-negligible impacts onsoftware and system designs. Orchestrating the workloads in a complex computing system andachieving a balance between efficiency and programmability requires the computer architect togain a thorough understanding of the workload and the system. On the other hand, instead ofsolely focusing on performance, a modern system could have multiple optimization targets, includingreliability, power efficiency, expandability, security, and even environmental sustainability. It ischallenging to properly define comprehensive and quantitative metrics for these targets and inspectthe relations between different design choices and these metrics.

To identify key challenges and explore future research directions in computer architecture, theNSF-sponsoredWorkshop on Redefining the Future of Computer Architecture from First Principles(Arch-1) provides a forum for leading experts in the relevant research thrusts of computer architecture,specifically architecture, compiler, operating systems, software stack, system integration,and applications to brainstorm the latest research progress and discuss their visions of redefiningthe future of computer architecture in the next 10-15 years. The goal of this workshop is to helpthe community to brainstorm and identify the grand challenges of modern computer architecturedesigns that are introduced by the advances in computing paradigm, computing devices, and computingapplications and to discuss possible disruptive technologies that could reform the architectureat various abstraction levels or even break the boundaries between these levels that correspond tothe conventional partition of the system stack. The workshop assembled over 50 researchers andleaders from academia, industry, and government. The first day of the workshop was formatted as4 panels and 2 breakout rooms covering application, architecture, software, and system. A (virtual)poster session was held at the end of the first day in a VR environment. On the last day, the attendeeswere grouped into 4 roundtables on these 4 themes. A report that summarizing the views expressed by the attendees was compiled and submitted to the NSF, including five major recommendations about the critical research topics and the urgent needs of the academia.
